The types of cancer listed include breast, prostate, colorectal, ovarian, and pancreatic cancer.

Fanconi syndrome is a rare inherited disorder that affects the kidne. It can cause problems with absorbing important nutrients, leading to low levels of certain minerals in the blood and urine. People with Fanconi syndrome may also have an increased risk of developing other health issues, including bone abnormalities, anemia, and skin rashes.

Some tips for responding to a Zika virus infection include avoiding mosquito bites by wearing long-sleeved shirts and pants, using insect repellent, staying in air-conditioned or well-screened areas, and reducing outdoor activities during peak mosquito hours (dusk to dawn). If you do get bitten, carefully monitor yourself for any symptoms of the virus and seek medical attention if necessary. Additionally, be sure to clean and disinfect frequently touched surfaces regularly and wash your hands often with soap and water.

An infection caused by nonpathogenic intestinal amoebae is called Entamoeba histolytica. It is a type of parasitic protozoan infection that affects the digestive system and can cause severe diarrheal illness.

Gastritis is inflammation of the stomach lining. It can be caused by infection, medications, autoimmune diseases, or excessive alcohol consumption. Symptoms include abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting, and sometimes blood in the stool. Treatment depends on the cause but usually includes lifestyle changes such as quitting smoking, reducing alcohol intake, and eating a balanced diet. Medicines may also be prescribed to reduce inflammation and protect the stomach lining.

Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS) is a genetic disorder in which the body is unable to respond to normal amounts of testosterone, causing the development of male characteristics to be halted or delayed. Individuals with AIS may have varying levels of masculinity, ranging from completely female physical appearance to moderate male physical characteristics. Signs and symptoms of AIS can include infertility, undescended testicles, sparse pubic hair, and breast enlargement.

Megacolon is a rare medical condition in which the large intestine becomes greatly enlarged and loses its ability to contract. This causes stool to become trapped in the colon, leading to severe discomfort, bloating, and constipation. It is typically caused by a problem with the nerves controlling the muscles in the colon, but can also be due to other underlying conditions like spinal cord injuries or multiple sclerosis. Treatment usually involves medications to relax the muscles in the colon and/or surgery to remove a portion of the colon.

Lung cancer is a type of cancer that starts in the lungs and can spread to other parts of the body. It is the leading cause of cancer deaths in both men and women, according to the American Cancer Society. There are several risk factors for developing lung cancer, including smoking, exposure to second-hand smoke, air pollution, genetics, and radon gas. Symptoms may include coughing, shortness of breath, fatigue, chest pain, and weight loss. Treatment options depend on the stage of the disease, but may include surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, targeted therapies, or immunotherapy.

Diamond-Blackfan anemia (DBA) is a rare inherited bone marrow failure disorder characterized by low levels of red blood cells, white blood cells and platelets. It affects infants, children and young adults. The cause of DBA is unknown, but it is thought to be caused by genetic mutations. Symptoms may include fatigue, pale skin, shortness of breath, easy bruising or bleeding, and delayed growth. Treatment usually involves regular blood transfusions, folate supplementation, and in some cases, medicines that help the bone marrow produce more blood cells.

Otitis externa is an inflammation of the external auditory canal that can be caused by a variety of factors including bacteria, fungi, chemicals, trauma, or even swimming. The most common symptoms include ear pain, itching, swelling, discharge, and hearing loss. Potential complications may include scarring, infection of the mastoid bone behind the ear, and even meningitis if the infection spreads to the brain. The outcome depends on how soon the condition is diagnosed and treated.

Vasovagal syncope is a type of fainting caused by reduced blood flow to the brain due to a drop in blood pressure and an abnormally high level of vasopressin, which is a hormone released during stressful situations. It usually occurs with emotional or physical stress such as fear, anxiety, inten,or extreme pain.

Follicular thyroid cancer is a type of thyroid cancer that starts in the follicular cells of the thyroid gland. It is one of the most common types of thyroid cancer, accounting for about 15-20% of cases. The exact cause of follicular thyroid cancer is not known but it is thought to be due to genetic changes which can be inherited or acquired during life. 
The main symptom of follicular thyroid cancer is a lump in the neck which can be felt by physical examination. Other symptoms may include difficulty swallowing, hoarseness, coughing, or ear pain. In some cases, there may also be enlargement of the thyroid gland, painless swelling in the front of the neck, or swelling in other parts of the body such as the voice box (larynx). 
The diagnosis of follicular thyroid

Jaundice has been documented since ancient times, and was thought to be caused by an imbalance in the body's humours. It was believed that jaundice could be caused by an excess of black bile, which was thought to cause melancholy. In the 1800s, scientists discovered that jaundice was actually due to a buildup of bilirubin in the blood, which is caused by a problem with the liver. Today, jaundice is usually treatable and can range from mild to severe depending on the underlying cause.

Parasystole is a type of arrhythmia characterized by an irregularly spaced sequence of two or more normal heartbeats. It usually occurs in the presence of another rhythm disturbance such as atrial fibrillation. Diagnosis involves ident asing abnormal heart rhythms with an electrocardiogram (ECG).

The primary method for preventing tracheitis is to avoid contact with people who are known to have a cold or allergy, and to practice good hygiene by washing your hands frequently and avoiding touching your face or other people. Additionally, it's important to get enough sleep, exercise regularly, and eat a healthy diet in order to strengthen your immune system and reduce your risk of developing tracheitis.

Coronary artery dual ostia is a medical term that refers to when there are two openings or outlets from the coronary arteries, instead of one. This can occur when there is an abnormal division in the arteries near the heart.

Primary prevention for hearing impairment is the process of taking steps to reduce the risk of developing hearing loss or other hearing problems. This can include avoiding loud noises, wearing ear protection when exposed to loud sounds, getting regular hearing checks, and treating any underlying medical conditions that may be causing hearing loss.

An electrocardiogram (ECG) can help to detect any underlying cardiac abnormalities which may be present due to the presence of an amoebic liver abscess. It is also used to monitor the heart's function and rhythm during treatment.

Prostatitis is an inflammation of the prostate gland caused by bacterial or non-bacterial infections, trauma, or immune system disorders. The main symptoms include pain during urination, difficulty urinating, and frequent urination. In some cases, patients may also experience fever, chills, and back pain. Treatment depends on the cause, but may involve antibiotics, lifestyle modifications, and other medications.

Infarction is a process that occurs when an area of tissue dies due to lack of blood supply. The morphology of arteries has an effect on the likelihood of infarction occurring, as some artery configurations are more likely to cause blockages or narrowing which can lead to insufficient blood flow.

The causes of chest pain in children can be varied and range from mild to serious conditions. Some common causes include respiratory tract infections, asthma, pneumonia, bronchitis, heartburn, pleurisy, and pulmonary embolism. Other possible causes include musculoskeletal problems such as pulled muscles or broken bones, tuberculosis, and cancer. It is important to seek medical attention if your child is experiencing chest pain so that a diagnosis can be made and treatment started as soon as possible.

Currently, the most widely available information on hypogonadism is that it is a condition in which the body does not produce enough testosterone or other hormones necessary for normal sexual development and functioning. Symptoms include low sex drive, fatigue, depression, and erectile dysfunction. Treatment typically involves lifestyle changes such as exercising more and eating a healthy diet, as well as medications and/or supplements to replace the missing hormones.

Carotenoderma is a skin condition caused by excessive consumption of foods high in carotene, such as carrots, sweet potatoes, pumpkin, spinach, kale, and other leafy greens. It is characterized by a yellow-orange discoloration of the skin, especially on the face, that can be itchy or flaky. Other symptoms may include dryness, scaling, and cracking of the skin.

Roseola is a mild viral illness that typically affects young children and is characterized by a high fever, runny nose, sore throat, headache, and rash. The fever can last up to 10 days and symptoms usually resolve within two weeks. Although there is no specific treatment for roseola, supportive care such as rest, fluids, and acetaminophen (Tylenol) to reduce fever and discomfort can help.

The phrase “Vasa: Praevia” refers to a condition in which one or more of the major blood vessels in the pelvis (the vasa) are present before birth (praevia). This can lead to complications during pregnancy, childbirth and afterward.

The most common treatment for Glucagonoma is surgery to remove the tumor, followed by medications to control blood sugar levels and hormone replacement therapy. In some cases, radiation or chemotherapy may be used as well.

There are four main types of breathing patterns: normal, shallow, rapid, and irregular. Normal breathing is when you inhale and exhale at a regular rate. Shallow breathing is when you take short, quick breaths. Rapid breathing is when you breat 
he deeply but quickly. And irregular breathing is when your breathing pattern is inconsistent or unpredictable.

The human retina consists of a thin layer of cells that line the inner surface of the eye. It is responsible for converting light into nerve impulses, which are then sent to the brain via the optic nerve. The retina is composed of several layers of tissue including the photoreceptors (rods and cones) which absorb light, the pigment epithelium, the outer nuclear layer, the inner nuclear layer, and the ganglion cell layer. These layers work together to capture and transmit visual information from the eye to the brain.

Ultrasound can be used to help diagnose neutropenia by measuring the size and shape of organs such as the spleen, which can become enlarged in patients with low levels of neutrophils. It can also be used to guide the placement of a central line, if necessary, and to monitor the response to treatment.

The staging of extranodal NK-T-cell lymphoma is based on the Ann Arbor classification system, which includes stages I through IV. Stage I refers to localized disease, meaning that it is confined to one area and has not spread beyond it. Stage II indicates regional disease, meaning it has spread to nearby lymph nodes or organs. Stage III indicates distant metastasis, meaning it has spread to other areas of the body. Finally, stage IV indicates advanced disease, meaning it has spread to multiple sites in the body.

An assay is a process of testing something to determine its composition or quality. In the case of coins, it's a test to determine their purity. The term "assay of coins" refers to the process of testing coins to determine their purity.

Dysfunctional uterine bleeding is a type of abnormal uterine bleeding that occurs in women who are not pregnant or menopaus. It is caused by hormonal imbalances and can often be treated with hormones.

Salivary gland tumors are growths that develop from the cells of the salivary glands, which produce and secrete saliva into the mouth. The most common type of salivary gland tumor is an adenoma, which is a benign (non-cancerous) tumor. Other types of salivary gland tumors include pleomorphic adenomas, myoepitheliomas, carcinomas, and sarcomas. Symptoms of salivary gland tumors may include swelling or lumps in the mouth, difficulty chewing or swallowing, pain when swallowing, or changes in the amount or consistency of saliva. Treatment for salivary gland tumors depends on the type and stage of the tumor, but may include surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, or targeted therapy.
A cardiac biopsy is a procedure where a small piece of tissue from the heart is taken and examined under a microscope to look for signs of amyloid deposits.

The most important thing to remember when dealing with acute diarrhea is to stay hydrated by drinking plenty of fluids such as water, juices and soups. It's also important to monitor your fluid intake and make sure you are not becoming dehydrated. Additionally, it can be beneficial to eat small, easy-to-digest meals and snacks, avoid foods that may cause discomfort, and consider using over-the-counter medications if recommended by a medical professional.

The hyoid bone is a U-shaped bone located in the throat, just below the tongue and above the chin. It serves as an anchor for many of the muscles that move the tongue and other structures in the mouth. Its main function is to support the movements of the tongue, which are essential for speech, swallowing, and chewing. Additionally, it also helps to protect important structures such as the trachea, esophagus, and larynx.

The most common laboratory tests performed on patients with an abscess in the appendicular region are a complete blood count (CBC), a metabolic panel, and a urinalysis. A CBC may reve ine an elevated white blood cell count, which is indicative of inflammation or infection. A metabolic panel can help to identify signs of dehydration, kidney damage, or other complications related to the infection. A urinalysis can detect red blood cells, white blood cells, bacteria, or protein in the urine, which can indicate the presence of an infection. Additionally, a culture of the abscess fluid may be taken to determine the specific cause of the infection.

An electrocardiogram (ECG) is a test that records the electrical activity of your heart. It has 12 leads, each of which records the electrical activity from a different area of your heart. The ECG machine will record the electrical signals as waves on a graph. Each waveform represents the electrical activity at a particular moment in time.

Menkes disease is a rare inherited disorder that affects the kidne, causing it to lose cells that help absorb essential nutrients and minerals. It is characterized by severe progressive deterioration of the skin, hair, muscles, and nervous system.

Strep throat is a bacterial infection caused by group A streptococci, which can lead to inflammation and soreness of the throat, tonsils, and other areas of the upper respiratory tract. Symptoms include sore throat, fever, swollen tonsils, headache, nausea, vomiting, and pain when swallowing. Treatment includes antibiotics and rest. It's important to seek medical attention if symptoms become severe or last more than a few days.

The lymphatic duct is a tube that carries lymph from the lymph nodes to the heart. It is part of the lymphatic system, which helps fight infections and other diseases by draining excess fluid from the body.

Filariasis and screening are not related. Filariasis is a parasitic disease caused by worms from the Filaria genus, while screening is the process of testing for certain health conditions or diseases.

Common infections observed in individuals who have undergone transplant surgery include bacterial, viral and fungal infections such as pneumonia, urinary tract infection, gastroenteritis and yeast infection. Additionally, patients may also develop complications related to immunosuppression such as skin cancer, infection due to parasites, and reactivation of latent infections such as herpes simplex or tuberculosis.

Burns are a type of trauma that can have serious consequences depending on the severity and location of the injury. The most common complication of burns is pain, which can be treated with medication or other methods such as local anesthetics. Other possible complications include infection, skin grafting, scarring, and even death if the burn is severe enough. The prognosis depends on how quickly medical attention is received and the severity of the burn.

Hepatopulmonary Syndrome (HPS) is a form of pulmonary hypertension, which is classified as a group of disorders characterized by high blood pressure in the vessels leading from the heart to the lungs.

An inferior vena cava filter is a small device that is implanted in the veins of the legs to prevent blood clots from traveling to the lungs. It works by catching and trapping the clots in the filter, which prevents them from reaching the lungs where they could cause serious damage.

Femoral hernias are more common in women than men, and they usually occur in middle-aged adults. They are also more common in people who are overweight or obese, and can be caused by pressure on the abd. from straining during bowel movements, pregnancy, or repeated heavy lifting.

Scabies is a contagious skin condition caused by mites called Sarcoptes scabiei. It is classified as a parasitic infestation, since the mite burrows into the skin to feed on skin cells. Symptoms of scabies include intenDescriptor: 16px; font-family: 'Open Sans', sans-serif; font-size: 14px; font-weight: 700; color: #333333;">describe symptoms of scabies such as itching, rash, blisters, and pimples. Treatment involves administration of topical or oral medications, depending on the severity of the case.

Coronary artery dissections can be classified into two categories: spontaneous and traumatic. Spontaneous coronary artery dissection (SCAD) occurs without an identifiable cause, while traumatic coronary artery dissection (TCA) is caused by physical injury to the chest or heart.

Delta waves are one of the five basic types of brain wave patterns, and they are associated with deep sleep. They have a slow frequency between 0.5 to 4 Hz and are typically seen in Stage 3 or 4 of sleep. Delta waves indicate that the person is in a very relaxed state and are often referred to as the “delta” stage of sleep.

Pick's disease, also known as frontotemporal dementia, is a rare neurodegenerative disorder that affects the frontal and temporal lobes of the brain. It is characterized by progressive loss of cognitive abilities such as language, behavior, and motor skills.

The primary role of Echo in an emergency situation is to provide real-time assistance and guidance to healthcare professionals, helping them make decisions quickly and accurately. It can also help with patient triage, which involves sorting patients into categories based on their severity of illness or injury.

Bioidentical hormone replacement therapy (BHRT) is a personalized treatment plan that uses hormones that are identical in structure and function to the body's own hormones. It is designed to replace deficient or imbalanced hormones, helping to restore overall health and wellness. BHRT can help alleviate symptoms of menopause and andropause as well as other conditions related to hormonal imbalance.

The connection between the jaw and arthropods is that both of them share a common ancestor who had a jointed jaw, or "arthropod-like" jaw, which allowed them to chew food more effectively. This trait was then passed down through evolution, and is now seen in many different species today.

Ebola is a viral disease caused by a group of viruses belonging to the Filoviridae family and the genus Ebolavirus. It is spread through contact with an infected animal or person, via direct contact with their bodily fluids such as saliva, blood, urine, and feces. The virus can also be spread through contact with contaminated surfaces. Symptoms include fever, headache, chills, muscle pain, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. In severe cases it can lead to organ failure and death.

Type 1 diabetes mellitus is a chronic condition in which the body's immune system attacks and destroys the cells in the pancreas that produce insulin. This causes high levels of glucose to build up in the blood and an inability to regulate blood sugar levels.

Candesartan is an angiotensin II receptor blocker used to treat high blood pressure and heart failure. It works by blocking a chemical in the body that causes blood vessels to narrow, which lowers blood pressure and reduces the workload of the heart. Side effects may include dizziness, headache, fatigue, and coughing.

Tension headaches can be caused by a variety of conditions, including muscle tension in the neck and scalp, stress, eye strain, and poor posture. Penile carcinoma is a rare form of cancer that affects the skin on the penis. Anesthesia and the monitoring of anesthetic are important for patient safety during surgery or other medical procedures. This helps ensure that the patient is safe throughout the procedure and recovering well afterwards.

A cyst in the bile duct is an abnormal fluid-filled sac that can form anywhere along the bile duct, which carries bile from the liver to the gallbladder and small intestine. It can cause blockage of the bile duct, resulting in jaundice, itching, and other symptoms.

Second-degree AV block is a type of heart rhythm disorder in which the electrical impulses from the top chambers of your heart (atria) take longer to reach the bottom chambers (ventricles). Atrial fibrillation is a type of irregular heart rhythm that can increase your risk of stroke, heart failure and other complications. Intermediate-density lipoprotein (IDL) is a type of cholesterol found in the blood that is made up of both protein and fat. Nephrotic Syndrome is a kidney disorder characterized by a decrease in the filtration rate of the glomerulus, which leads to increased proteinuria and edema. The hallmark features are heavy proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, hyperlipidemia, and edema. Treatment includes controlling the underlying cause, management of symptoms, and dietary modifications.

Pericarditis induced by radiation is an inflammation of the lining of the heart (the pericardium) caused by exposure to radiation. It can cause chest pain, difficulty breathing, and fluid buildup around the heart. Treatment typically includes rest, medications, and sometimes surgery.

Cerebral gliomas (also known as gliomatosis cerebri) are tumors that arise from the supportive tissue of the brain, such as the meninges or the blood vessels supplying the brain. Rett syndrome is a rare neurological disorder that affects mostly girls. It is characterized by problems with speech, motor skills, and cognitive abilities. Glioblastoma multiforme is a type of aggressive brain cancer that affects the glial cells in the brain and spinal cord. The prognosis for glioblastoma multiforme is very poor, with an average survival rate of only 14 months.

Enoxaparin is a low molecular weight heparin used to treat and prevent deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism. Delirium tremens (DTs) is a condition that can develop after long-term alcohol use. It is characterized by tremors, confusion, hallucinations, and other symptoms. Congenital Rubella Syndrome (CRS) is a condition that can occur in babies whose mothers are infected with the rubella virus during pregnancy. Symptoms may include hearing loss, heart defects, eye abnormalities, developmental delays and learning disabilities. The severity of symptoms depends on how early in the pregnancy the mother was infected. CRS is completely preventable through vaccination. It's important for pregnant women to make sure they are up-to-date on all their immunizations, including the MMR vaccine.

Haff is a rare genetic disorder that affects the way the body breaks down certain proteins. It is caused by mutations in the HSD gene, which provides instructions for making an enzyme called hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase. People with Haff have lower-than-normal levels of this enzyme, which leads to high levels of certain proteins in their bodies. This can cause damage to organs, including the kidneys, eyes, brain, heart, and blood vessels. Symptoms may include jaundice at birth, vision loss, seizures, developmental delays, and other health problems.
Typhoid fever has two stages, an initial stage with a high fever and a later stage with a lower fever. The fever during both stages is classified as a systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS).

Silent thyroiditis is an autoimmune condition in which the thyroid gland is attacked by the body's own immune system, leading to inflammation and temporary destruction of the gland without causing any symptoms. The cause is unknown but it may be related to genetic factors or environmental triggers such as stress. Treatment consists of rest and supportive care including pain medications if needed.

Wrist drop is a test used to measure the strength and coordination of the hand muscles by having the patient make a fist and then letting go of the fingers one at a time. The examiner measures how long it takes for all five fingers to let go. A slow wrist drop indicates weakness or impairment in the hand muscles.

Constipation is a common condition that affects the digestive system, causing infrequent or difficult bowel movements. Symptoms can include feeling bloated, passing hard stools, and having an urgent need to have a bowel movement. There are many things you can do to manage constipation, such as increasing fiber intake, drinking more water, exercising regularly, and avoiding foods high in fat and sugar. Cardiac radionuclide imaging is a test that uses small amounts of radioactive material, called tracers, to produce images of the heart and its blood vessels. Chickenpox is a highly contagious disease caused by the varicella-zoster virus and is most commonly seen in children. It is characterized by an itchy rash, fever, and blisters all over the body. The best way to prevent chickenpox is with the chickenpox vaccine, which is usually given to children between ages 12 months and 18 years old. The vaccine is approximately 90% effective in preventing the disease. Treatment typically includes surgery, radiation therapy, and chemotherapy.

Glycogen Storage Disease Type III (GSD III) is an inherited disorder in which the body cannot properly store and use energy. It is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme glucose-6-phosphatase, which is needed to break down glycogen, a form of stored energy found in the liver and muscles. Symptoms may include jaundice, fatigue, vomiting, poor feeding, stunted growth and intellectual disability. Treatment includes dietary management, enzyme replacement therapy, and insulin.

Papillomas are benign tumors that can appear anywhere on the body, but most commonly in the mouth and throat. They are caused by a virus called Human Papilloma Virus (HPV). Symptoms of papillomas may include a lump or bump in the mouth or throat, painless swelling, difficulty swallowing, hoarseness, or a change in the voice. Treatment for papillomas includes surgical removal if necessary, but often the virus will clear up on its own.

Papillary necrosis is a rare condition which affects the kidneys, causing them to become inflamed and damaged. It is usually caused by an autoimmune disorder or an infection, but can also be due to certain medications or drugs. Symptoms include fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, and pain in the side or back. Treatment involves identifying and treating the underlying cause, as well as supportive care such as rest, fluids, and pain management. Frontotemporal lobar degeneration (FTLD) is a neurodegenerative disorder that affects the front and/or side of the Temporal Lobes, as well as the Frontal Lobe of the brain. It can cause changes in personality or behavior, language difficulties, and problems with motor skills. Symptoms usually appear between the ages of 40 and 60, but may occur earlier or later in life.

Whipworms are parasitic worms that can infect the large intestine and cause an infection called trichuriasis. Symptoms may include abdominal pain, diarrhea, and weight loss. In severe cases, it can lead to anemia, malnutrition, and even blindness if left untreated. Treatment involves administering anti-parasitic drugs and deworming medicines. It's important to maintain good hygiene and sanitation to prevent whipworm infections.

Thymic carcinoma is a type of cancer that starts in the thymus gland. It can be classified into four stages, with Stage IV being the most advanced. At this stage, the cancer has spread to other organs such as the lungs, bones, or brain.

A Holter monitor is a device that continuously records your heart activity over a period of time, usually 24 or 48 hours. It's used to help diagnose certain types of heart rhythm problems. The monitor attaches to your body with adhesive patches and measures the electrical activity of your heart throughout the day.

Gynecologic hemorrhage is a type of bleeding from the female reproductive tract that can be caused by a variety of conditions, including fibroids, endometriosis, and polyps. It is usually treated with medications or surgery.

Aortic regurgitation occurs when the valve between the left ventricle and the aorta does not close properly, allowing blood to flow backward into the left ventricle instead of out to the body. This can occur due to weakening or damage to the valve, which can be caused by a variety of conditions such as coronary artery disease, hypertension, or aging. The weakened valve allows blood to flow backward, leading to increased pressure in the left ventricle and decreased pressure in the rest of the body.

Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS) is a genetic disorder in which males are born with normal X and Y chromosomes but have an inherited mutation that prevents their bodies from responding to the male hormones, called androgens. This can lead to incomplete sexual development and infertility.

Osteochondroma is a benign bone tumor that typically occurs in the knee, shoulder, or long bones of the arms and legs during adolescence or early adulthood. It is composed of cartilage and bone, and can sometimes cause pain, swelling, and limited mobility. Surgery to remove it may be recommended if it is causing symptoms or poses a risk of becoming cancerous.

Fever is an increase in the body's temperature caused by the body fighting off an infection or other illness. It is usually accompanied by other symptoms such as feeling tired, headache, and muscle aches.

Antiphospholipid Syndrome is a type of autoimmune disorder in which the body's immune system mistakenly attacks its own cells and proteins. In the case of Antiphospholipid Syndrome, the body attacks protein components of cell membranes called phospholipids. This can cause problems with blood clotting and pregnancy complications due to increased risk of miscarriage, stillbirth, or birth defects.

The diagnosis from a CT scan for tongue cancer would be an image of the tumor and its location on the tongue. It can also provide information about the size and extent of the tumor, as well as any spread to nearby lymph nodes or other organs.

Zoonotic diseases are those that can be passed from animals to humans. Examples of such diseases include rabies, salmonellosis, campylobacteriosis, giardiasis, and cryptosporidiosis. The FSH receptor (FSHR) is a protein found on the surface of cells that binds to the hormone follicle stimulating hormone (FSH). It plays an important role in regulating the development and function of the reproductive system, as well as other organs such as the brain, bones, skin and heart. The exact cause of constitutional delay of growth and puberty is not fully understood, but it is believed to be due to a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Tenecteplase is a type of drug called a thrombolytic agent, which helps to dissolve blood clots. It is used in the treatment of heart attack and stroke. The exact mechanism of action of tenecteplase is not fully understood, but it appears to work by breaking down the clot-forming proteins in the body, thus helping to restore normal blood flow. It can be admin 
istered either intravenously or as an injection into the muscle. Common side effects include bleeding, nausea, and headache.

Myeloperoxidase deficiency is a rare genetic disorder in which the body is unable to properly use an enzyme called myeloperoxidase. This enzyme helps fight infections and break down certain molecules in the body. People with myeloperoxidase deficiency have an increased risk of developing serious infections, particularly in the lungs and urinary tract. Treatment involves replacing the missing enzyme or taking medications that mimic its effects.

Isolated isovaleric acidemia is an inherited disorder in which the body cannot properly break down certain proteins. This leads to high levels of isovalerylglycine and other related compounds in the blood, causing damage to the brain, nervous system, and other organs. Symptoms may include jaundice, vomiting, seizures, and muscle weakness. Treatment involves a special diet that avoids certain proteins, as well as medications and supplements.

Laboratory tests that may be done to investigate palpitations include a complete blood count, thyroid function test, electrolyte panel, liver function test, and cardiac enzyme levels. An ECG or echocardiogram may also be ordered to rule out any underlying heart conditions.

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is a type of cancer that affects the white blood cells. The main treatment for ALL is chemotherapy, which uses medications to destroy the abnormal cells in the body. Other treatments may include radiation therapy, targeted therapy, or stem cell transplantation.

Surgery can be an important part of the treatment for Erdheim-Chester disease, depending on the location and extent of the lesions. It may involve removal of tumor masses or biopsies to confirm a diagnosis, as well as debulking procedures to reduce symptoms and improve quality of life.

Lipoid pneumonia is a type of lung inflammation caused by the presence of large amounts of fat particles in the lungs. It is usually caused by aspiration of foreign material into the lungs, or by inhaling fats and oils from smoke or other sources. Symptoms may include coughing, shortness of breath, fever, chest pain, and trouble breathing. Treatment typically includes rest, fluids, and medications to help reduce inflammation. Conjunctivitis, commonly known as "pink eye", is an inflammation of the conjunctiva, a thin layer of cells that line the inside of the eyelid and part of the eye. It can be caused by a variety of infections, including viruses, bacteria, and fungi, or it can be due to allergies or environmental irritants. Secondary prevention of chest pain means taking steps to reduce the risk of a heart attack or other cardiovascular diseases after they have already occurred. This can include lifestyle changes such as exercising, eating healthy, and managing stress, as well as medications and medical procedures.

Alopecia, also known as hair loss, has been documented throughout history and is believed to have many different causes. Congestive heart failure is a condition that can interact with several different types of drugs, including those used to treat high blood pressure, diabetes, and chest infections. Lung abscess is a collection of pus in the lungs, usually caused by bacterial infection. It can be caused by respiratory tract infections such as pneumonia, or may develop following surgery, trauma, or other medical conditions. Symptoms include fever, chest pain, coughing with bloody sputum, shortness of breath, and fatigue. Treatment includes antibiotics and drainage of the abscess if necessary. In some cases, surgery may be required to remove the abscess.

The recommended medical treatment for Mallory-Weiss syndrome is rest, pain relievers and sometimes surgery to repair any tears in the lining of the digestive tract.

Fifth disease, also known as erythema infectiosum, is a mild, common childhood illness caused by the human parvovirus B19. It typically begins with fever and a bright red rash on the face that spreads to other body areas. Other symptoms may include sore throat, headache, stomach discomfort, and swollen lymph nodes. The disease usually resolves within two weeks, but some people may experience fatigue and joint pain for months after infection.

Osteoid and osteoma are both types of bone tissue, but they have different structures and functions. Osteoid is a soft, loose connective tissue that forms the matrix of bones during growth and repair. Osteoma is a benign tumor composed of compact bone tissue.

Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS) is a genetic disorder in which males are born with an X chromosome and typically have normal female external genitalia at birth. However, they lack sensitivity to male hormones called androgens, which can cause infertility and other medical issues such as undescended testicles, breast development, and pubic hair. Potential complications include infertility, kidney stones, and increased risk of certain types of cancer. The expected outcome depends on the severity of the case but generally includes appropriate medical management, hormone therapy, and gender reassignment surgery.

Percutaneous closure for atrial septal defect is a procedure to close the hole in the heart that has been present since birth (congenital). It is done by inserting a catheter into a vein and guiding it to the heart. Once the catheter reaches the defect, a device is used to close it up. This procedure is less invasive than open heart surgery and has a lower risk of complications.

There are many potential causes of pelvic pain, including infections, urinary tract stones, endometriosis, ovarian cysts, fibroids, and sexually transmitted diseases. It is important to get checked by a medical professional to determine the cause and proper treatment.

A urea cycle disorder (UCD) is an inherited metabolic disorder in which the body is unable to properly break down and remove ammonia from the bloodstream. This build up of ammonia can cause serious health problems, including seizures, coma, and even death if not treated promptly. UCDs are caused by mutations in one of several genes that code for proteins involved in the urea cycle, resulting in either reduced or non-functional enzyme activity. Treatment usually involves a special diet, medications, and sometimes even a liver transplant.

Roseola is a viral illness that typically affects young children. It is characterized by fever, headache, runny nose, and rash. The rash usually appears as flat or raised red spots on the skin. Most cases of roseola are mild and resolve without treatment, however, it is important to stay hydrated and get plenty of rest.

A zinc deficiency can have serious health consequences, including weakened immunity, slowed wound healing, and problems with growth and development. It can also lead to diarrhea, vomiting, and skin discoloration.

The Hyperosmolar Hyperglycemic State (HHS) is a rare but serious complication of diabetes mellitus that is characterized by high blood glucose levels, along with increased urination and thirst. Symptoms may include confusion, drowsiness, dry mouth and skin, increased hunger, and unusual breath odor. Treatment involves intensive insulin therapy, fluid replacement, and electrolyte balance.

Sarcomatoid carcinoma is a rare and aggressive form of lung cancer that has been reported since the early 20th century. It was first described by German pathologist Franz Xaver Neumann in 1935, who named it “sarcomatoid carcinoma” because of its resemblance to sarcoma, or connective tissue tumor. While it accounts for less than 5% of all cases of lung cancer, it is associated with a worse prognosis due to its aggressiveness and resistance to treatment.

Vulvar cancer is a type of cancer that affects the skin on and around the vulva, which are the external female genitalia. It is a rare form of cancer but can be very serious if not detected and treated early. Symptoms may include itchy or irritated skin, a lump in the vulva, pain during sex, bleeding between periods, or a change in the look of the vulva.

VIPoma is a rare form of cancer that arises from specialized cells in the pancreas called islet cells. These islet cells produce hormones that regulate blood sugar levels. VIPoma usually presents with high levels of a particular hormone called vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP). The main symptoms are elevated levels of VIP in the blood and urine, as well as signs of hyperglycemia or diabetes mellitus. Treatment typically involves surgery to remove the tumor, followed by targeted therapy to reduce levels of VIP.

Subependymoma is a benign tumor that arises from the lining of the brain's ventricles, called the ependyma. It usually occurs in children and young adults, and can cause symptoms such as headache, nausea, vomiting, seizures, and vision problems. The risk of recurrence after surgery is low, but there is also a risk of long-term or permanent neurological damage due to the location of the tumor.

A mycotic aneurysm is a sac-like bulge in an artery caused by an infection. It usually occurs due to bacterial infections such as those caused by bacteria from the Mycobacterium tuberculosis family. The bulge is caused when the walls of the artery become weak and stretch, allowing blood to flow into the sac. If left untreated, it can lead to serious complications including stroke or even death.

Dermatofibroma is a benign skin tumor caused by the proliferation of fibroblasts in the deep reticular layer of the skin. It is believed to be due to trauma, inflammation or irritation of the skin. The exact cause is unknown but it is not cancerous and does not require treatment.

Anemia of chronic disease is a type of anemia that is caused by long-term health conditions, such as cancer, HIV/AIDS, or kidney disease. It is characterized by low levels of red blood cells and is usually managed with iron supplements, folate supplements, and sometimes medications.

A Pilon fracture is a severe and complex broken ankle, usually caused by high energy trauma such as a car accident or fall from a great height. It involves the bones in the lower leg, ankle, and foot all at once, and can involve multiple fractures and dislocations. Treatment typically includes surgery to repair the fractures and realign the bones, followed by physical therapy for rehabilitation.

Dicumarol is a medication used to prevent blood clots in patients with heart disease or stroke. It works by blocking the effects of an enzyme called vitamin K epoxide reductase, which helps form clots in the body. The exact way that dicumarol prevents clots is not fully understood; however, it is known to reduce the risk of stroke and heart attack.

Gynecomastia is a benign enlargement of male breast tissue due to an imbalance in hormones that cause excessive growth of the glandular tissue. It can affect one or both breasts and may be present at birth or develop later in life. Complications include discom fort, skin irritation from rubbing against clothing, and emotional distress. The prognosis is usually good with surgical intervention or medications.

According to the ACC-AHA, type A coronary lesions are characterized by a single, large vessel luminal diameter stenosis with minimal or no plaque; type B coronary lesions are characterized by multiple, small vessel luminal diameter stenoses with moderate to severe plaque; and type C coronary lesions are characterized by total occlusion of one or more vessels.

Norovirus is a highly contagious virus that affects the stomach and intestines. It causes inflammation of the lining of the stomach or intestines, vomiting, diarrhea, and body aches. Symptoms usually last for 1-3 days but can last up to 10 days. The best way to prevent Norovirus infection is frequent hand washing, avoiding contact with people who are sick, and disinfecting frequently touched surfaces.

Kostmann syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by growth failure, neutropenia (low levels of certain white blood cells), and thrombocytopenia (low levels of blood platelets). It is caused by mutations in the gene that encodes for elastin, a protein found in many tissues throughout the body. Symptoms usually begin in infancy or early childhood and can include delayed puberty, recurrent infections, and bleeding gums. Treatment includes supportive care to manage symptoms, as well as medication or surgery to treat complications such as bleeding.

Autoimmune hepatitis is caused by an abnormal immune system response in which the body's own antibodies attack the liver cells, leading to inflammation and damage to the liver. The exact cause of this type of immune system dysfunction is unknown but it may be due to a combination of genetic, environmental, and/or viral factors.

Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID) is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in genes that code for proteins essential for normal development and functioning of the immune system. The X-linked inheritance pattern refers to when a gene responsible for a disease or trait is located on the X chromosome, which is one of the two sex chromosomes. In this case, males have only one X chromosome while females have two, so any mutation present on the X chromosome will be expressed more severely in males due to their lack of a second X chromosome to compensate.

Echocardiography is a type of ultrasound that can be used to examine the heart and its structures. It can help to detect abnormalities in the lungs, such as bleeding or fluid buildup, which could be causing hemoptysis.

The circulatory system is responsible for transporting oxygen, nutrients and other essential substances to cells throughout the body, as well as removing waste products from them. It works by pumping deoxygenated blood away from the heart, through the vessels and back to the heart so it can be re-oxygenated and then pumped around the body again.

Biochemistry is a branch of chemistry that studies the chemical processes in living organisms. It involves the study of carbohydrates as they are an important source of energy for cells. Peaked T waves are a type of abnormal heart rhythm that can be seen on an electrocardiogram (ECG). They indicate that the electrical impulses in the heart muscle are not conducting normally, which can be a sign of a heart condition such as coronary artery disease or myocardial infarction.

Splenic marginal zone lymphoma is a slow-g­rowing type of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma that usually affects middle-aged or elderly people. It is most commonly found in the spleen but can also involve other organs such as the bone marrow, liver, and digestive tract. The disease typically progresses over time, leading to anemia, thrombocytopenia, and other complications. The prognosis for patients with splenic marginal zone lymphoma depends on the stage of the disease, but generally it is not as aggressive as some other types of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.

Tropical Sprue, also known as Weil's Disease, is an infectious disease caused by a parasite called Entamoeba histolytica. It was first identified in the early 20th century and is most common in tropical climates where sanitation and hygiene are poor. Symptoms include fever, diarrhea, weight loss, and anemia. If left untreated, it can be fatal.

An esophageal stricture is a narrowing of the esophagus due to scarring from inflammation or injury, which makes it difficult for food and liquid to pass through. Biatrial enlargement is a change seen on an electrocardiogram (ECG or EKG) that indicates that the heart’s two upper chambers, the atria, are larger than normal. This can be caused by various medical conditions and may indicate an increased risk of cardiac arrhythmias and other complications.

Chromatography is a technique used to separate compounds or particles in a sample, such as proteins and other substances found in blood. It works by passing a liquid sample through a specialized medium which separates the components based on their different size and chemical properties. This allows for the isolation and purification of specific molecules from the mixture.

Anticonvulsant drugs are medications used to treat seizures and other neurologic conditions. They work by reducing abnormal electrical activity in the brain that can cause seizures. These drugs are also sometimes used to treat mood, anxiety, and other psychiatric disorders.

Budd-Chiari Syndrome (BCS) is a rare disorder in which the veins that carry blood from the liver to the heart become blocked or narrowed. This can cause abnormalities in the liver, bleeding, and scarring of the liver tissue. It is usually caused by a defective gene, but can also be caused by other conditions such as infections, cancer, or pregnancy. Symptoms may include jaundice, fatigue, abdominal pain, and swelling of the legs. Treatment includes medication, surgery, or a liver transplant.

MRI can be used to help diagnose epithelial ovarian tumors by providing additional information about the size, shape and location of the tumor as well as any surrounding tissue or fluid. It may also be used to detect some of the more subtle features of a tumor that could not be seen with other imaging tests such as CT scans.

Terson Syndrome is a rare medical condition that affects the heart and blood vessels. It is caused by an abnormality in the right coronary artery, which can lead to chest pain, irregular heart rhythms, heart failure, and other complications. Symptoms usually begin at an early age, but can also occur later in life. Treatment typically involves surgery or medications to improve symptoms and reduce the risk of complications.
The laboratory findings associated with Addison's disease include hyponatremia, hypokalemia, hyperaldosteronism, and increased levels of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH).

Esophagitis is inflammation of the esophagus, which is the tube that carries food from the mouth to the stomach. It can be caused by a variety of conditions including infection, medications, autoimmune diseases, and even certain medical procedures. Symptoms may include heartburn, chest pain, difficulty swallowing, nausea, and vomiting.

Intussusception is a type of obstruction in which one section of the bowel slides inside another section. It is most commonly caused by swallowing foreign objects, such as coins or batteries, or by parasitic worms. Other risk factors include birth defects, inflammatory bowel disease, and certain medical treatments.

Rift Valley fever is a mosquito-borne virus that can cause severe illness in both humans and animals. In humans, symptoms may include fever, headache, joint pain, muscle aches, nausea, vomiting, and exhaustion. In severe cases, it can also lead to neurologic complications such as encephalitis or meningitis.

Leiomyosarcoma is a rare type of soft tissue sarcoma that can be treated with surgery, chemotherapy and radiation therapy. Surgery may involve removing the tumor and some surrounding healthy tissue, while chemotherapy and radiation therapy are often used to reduce the risk of recurrence.

The natural history of aortic stenosis is that it typically progresses over time, leading to symptoms such as chest pain, shortness of breath, fatigue, and heart failure. Potential complications include heart arrhythmias, heart attack, and stroke. The likely outcome depends on how severe the stenosis is, but generally speaking surgery or other interventions may be necessary to improve symptoms or prolong life.

Dilated cardiomyopathy is a heart muscle disease that can cause abnormal changes in the heart's structure and function. Laboratory tests may show increased levels of certain enzymes, proteins, or hormones released into the blood stream as a result of heart muscle damage. Additionally, an echocardiogram may be used to measure the size and function of the heart, and an electrocardiogram (ECG) can detect any abnormal electrical activity in the heart.
Epilepsy has no direct connection to the heart, but some people with epilepsy may have an increased risk of developing heart rhythm abnormalities.

Autoimmune retinopathy is a condition in which the body's immune system attacks the cells of the retina, causing damage and potentially vision loss.

Paroxysmal AV block is a type of heart rhythm disorder in which the electrical impulses that coordinate the beating of your heart are delayed or interrupted. Alcohol withdrawal is a set of symptoms that can occur when someone who has been dependent on alcohol suddenly stops or reduces their drinking. It is important to seek medical help if you are trying to quit drinking as the symptoms can be severe and potentially life-threatening.
Cardiogenic shock is a type of shock caused by an inade,e of blood flow to the heart due to heart attack or other cardiac problems.

Complex Regional Pain Syndrome (CRPS) is a chronic condition that affects the arms, legs, hands and feet. It is believed to be caused by damage to or malfunction of the central nervous system, resulting in severe pain, swelling, and changes in skin color. Symptoms can include extreme sensitivity to touch, increased sweating, and changes in temperature and circulation. CRPS can significantly impact quality of life and may require long-term treatment.

Back pain is defined as discomfort or pain in the back that can range from a dull, constant ache to a sudden, sharp pain. It can be caused by a variety of conditions, including muscle strain, spasms and injuries.

There are many resources available that provide information about spina bifida, including the Spina Bifida Association and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC). The CDC states that spina bifida is a neural tube defect caused by failure of the neural tube to close properly in the first few weeks of development. It can cause life-long physical disabilities such as paralysis, bladder and bowel problems, and other complications. However, with proper medical care and support, individuals with spina bifida can lead healthy and fulfilling lives.

Barrett’s esophagus is a condition in which the lining of the lower esophagus changes due to long-term exposure to stomach acid. It is caused by gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and can lead to an increased risk of cancer of the esophagus. Symptoms may include heartburn, difficulty swallowing, chest pain, or vomiting. Treatment usually involves lifestyle modifications such as weight loss, avoidance of certain foods and beverages, and medications to reduce stomach acid. In some cases, surgery may be recommended.

A Flint murmur is an abnormal sound heard during a physical examination that indicates there may be a problem with the heart valves. It is named after the doctor who first described it in 1953, Dr. Arthur James Flint.

Patent Foramen Ovale (PFO) is a hole in the heart that some people are born with, located between the two upper chambers of the heart (the atria). It usually closes shortly after birth but in some cases it may remain open. A PFO can cause blood clots to form which can travel to the brain and cause a stroke.

Cretinism is a congenital disorder that results from a deficiency of thyroid hormones, leading to physical and mental retardation if untreated. It was first described in 1835 by German physicians who noted an unusually high rate of mental retardation among inhabitants of the island of Crete. The condition has since been found in other parts of the world with similar climate and dietary conditions.

The classification system used for Rhinosinusitis is based on the duration of symptoms and the amount of nasal congestion present. It includes acute rhinosinusitis, which is defined as a condition lasting less than 12 weeks; subacute rhinosinusitis, which is defined as a condition lasting between 12 and 16 weeks; and chronic rhinosinusitis, which is defined as a condition lasting longer than 16 weeks. Infertility is the inability to conceive after one year of unprotected sex. It affects about 10-15% of couples and can be caused by female factors, male factors or both. Treatment options depend on the cause but may include lifestyle changes, medications, intrauterine insemination, egg or sperm donation, or assisted reproductive technologies such as IVF.

Supraventricular tachycardia is a type of rapid heart rhythm that originates in the upper chambers of the heart (the atria). Complications from supraventricular tachycardia may include fainting, stroke, heart failure, or an abnormal heart rhythm called atrial fibrillation. The majority of people with supraventricular tachycardia will have a good outcome if treated promptly and correctly. Treatment typically includes medicines and sometimes procedures such as catheter ablation to destroy the extra electrical pathways that are causing the problem.

This reflex is important in maintaining blood pressure and heart rate when the body is under stress or during shock. It is also involved in regulating the autonomic nervous system, which controls involuntary body functions such as breathing, digestion and circulation.

Sclerosing encapsulating peritonitis is an inflammatory condition of the lining of the abdomen, which causes thickening and scarring of the peritoneum. The medical treatment for hypopharyngeal cancer typically includes surgery, radiation therapy and chemotherapy. Asperger’s syndrome is a form of high functioning autism which affects social interaction, communication, and restricted interests or activities. The symptoms usually become apparent in early childhood and can cause significant impairment in social, academic and occupational functioning. Potential complications include difficulty forming relationships, difficulty with transitions, anxiety, depression, and self-injurious behavior. Forecasted outcomes depend on the individual but typically involve improved social skills, increased independence, and better quality of life.

Neonatal sepsis is a serious infection that can occur in newborns, usually within the first few days of life. It is most commonly caused by bacteria from the mother’s genital tract, such as Escherichia coli and Staphylococcus aureus, but may also be due to other organisms including fungi. Symptoms include fever, lethargy, poor feeding, and difficulty breathing. Diagnosis is made through laboratory tests, such as blood cultures, urine cultures, cerebrospinal fluid analysis, and chest X-rays. Treatment typically includes antibiotics, fluids, and surgery if needed.

Congenital CMV is an abbreviation for congenital cytomegalovirus infection, which is a type of virus that can cause health problems in babies if they become infected with it while in the womb or shortly after birth. It is spread through contact with the urine or other bodily fluids of an infected person and can lead to hearing loss, vision impairment, developmental delays, and other complications.

Skin patches containing the opioid medication Fentanyl are used to treat chronic pain and provide relief from breakthrough pain. Glycogen Storage Disease (GSD) is a group of inherited disorders in which the body is unable to properly store and use glycogen, a type of starch that is found in muscles and other tissues. This can lead to symptoms such as muscle weakness, fatigue, abnormal heart rhythms, seizures, and brain damage. Treatment depends on the specific type of GSD but may include dietary management, lifestyle modifications, enzyme replacement therapy, or surgery.

Marasmus is a form of malnutrition that is characterized by weight loss, lack of energy, and muscle wasting. It is usually caused by an inade­quate diet or a deficiency in certain vitamins or minerals. The main treatments for marasmus are to ensure that the patient is getting adequate nutrition through proper diet and supplements if necessary. Additionally, any underlying medical conditions should be treated.

Gonorrhea is a sexually transmitted infection caused by bacteria called Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It is one of the most common sexually transmitted infections, and can affect both men and women. Symptoms may include a burning sensation when urinating, discharge from the penis or vagina, painful sexual intercourse, and lower abdominal pain. If left untreated, it can cause serious complications such as infertility, pelvic inflammatory disease, and ectopic pregnancy. The best way to prevent gonorrhea is to practice safe sex and use condoms.

Congenital heart block is a type of heart arrhythmia that occurs due to abnormal development of the electrical system of the heart before birth. It is caused by damage to the conduction system of the heart, which results in an impaired ability for the heart to effectively contract and pump blood throughout the body. Symptoms can range from mild to severe and may include fatigue, dizziness, fainting, or chest pain. Treatment usually involves medications and/or surgery to help regulate the heart's rhythm. More recently, advances in technology have allowed doctors to implant pacemakers or defibrillators to help manage symptoms.

The primary prevention method for Conjunctivitis is to practice good hygiene and avoid contact with people who have it. Washing your hands frequently, using clean cotton swabs to touch your eyes, and avoiding sharing personal items such as towels or face cloths can help reduce the risk of getting Conjunctivitis. Additionally, it's important to keep your environment clean by regularly disinfecting surfaces and objects that may be contaminated.

The National Cholesterol Education Program's Adult Treatment Panel III (ATP III) recommends that adults with hypercholesterolemia should have their LDL cholesterol level reduced to below 100mg/dl or less. Nocturia is a condition in which an individual wakes two or more times during the night to urinate. It is a common complaint that affects millions of people worldwide, and can be caused by a variety of factors such as drinking too much water, certain medications, or an underlying medical condition. There are many resources available online about nocturia, including websites from the National Kidney Foundation, Mayo Clinic, and WebMD.

Hormones can be classified into three main groups based on their chemical structure, endocrine system, and physiological effects: steroids, amines, and peptides. Steroids include sex hormones such as testosterone and estrogen, which regulate sexual development and reproductive functions in both males and females.
